Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Impurity Incorporation into Epitaxial Graphene on SiC
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Description: The goal of this research project is to develop a novel method to place controlled amounts of substitutional impurities into graphene grown on SiC, to physically and electronically characterize the doped structures, and to evaluate the changes in the film's properties. Impurities are implanted into a SiC wafer prior to graphene formation. The wafer is annealed to bring the impurity distribution near the surface. Then graphene is grown by sublimation of Si, simultaneously driving the impurities into the graphene film. After this process, the impurity distribution is characterized by surface analytical techniques as well as by electrical transport measurements. If successful, the method can also be applied to other two-dimensional materials.

Non-technical Description: Graphene, a single layer of carbon atoms bound together in a honeycomb lattice structure, has unique electrical and mechanical properties. Effective use of these properties requires the inclusion of predetermined amounts of impurity atoms (doping) in the films. The project develops a new method to incorporate controlled amounts of atoms into a single atomic layer of graphene, and provides graduate student training in an interdisciplinary environment. In addition, undergraduate students at the University of Minnesota and at Rutgers University, as well as high school teachers working at Georgia Tech, obtain direct hands-on research experience in the project as well as study materials and new understanding resulting from the project in courses taught by the principal investigators.

Intellectual merit: The collaboration funded by this proposal was directed at the formation of new, geometrical forms of graphene and the study of their properties. The Rutgers component of the collaboration dealt specifically with developing new forms of lithography to create strain controlled forms of graphene. This work provided new information and guidelines on the applicability of focused ion beam lithography, in particular, on the use of sub-nanometer He ion beams in the range of 10-30KeV energy. Critical conclusions illustrated the limits set by the basic ion-solid interactions including ion beam straggling, the formation of useful dimples as a form of nanoscale lithography not obtainable by other techniques and lithographic integrity by choice of substrate and ion beam parameters. For example there were startlingly and surprising differences between materials such as silicon, silicon carbide and sapphire. Overall the work provided unique example of this new form of ion beam lithography.

Broader impacts: The broader impacts dealt with student/post doc education. The He beam facility was used by two graduate student and two post-docs in various aspects of the program. As a result of the work this group developed an expertise in lithography practices and concepts and now represent the largest student/post-dock group trained in the use of He ion beam probes for lithography and other applications. The experience gained from these studies will be employed in PhD theses. Publications in preparation will allow dissemination of this experience to the broader scientific community. This is particularly valuables as He ion lithography is just beginning as a research tool. In addition the students experienced a new and growing form of scientific collaboration having interactions with sub-groups in other states and exchanging samples and ideas in weekly meetings.

Outcomes:

There is a well-recognized need to develop basis electronic materials that can replace silicon with high performance in term device speed and lower power consumption. Two dimensional materials (one to a few atomic layers thick) are thought to be one of the paths to such enhanced performance. One candidate, identified a few years ago, was graphene, a two dimensional form of carbon atoms which has demonstrated extraordinary electron mobility and speed. Unfortunately graphene does not show the characteristic property of a semiconductor, namely a band gap.

This collaborative research project is directed to the synthesis of new forms of graphene, possibly with the creation of a form with a band-gap. Earlier results from our group had shown strong indication of this property in special forms of graphene grown on silicon carbide (SiC). The indication of a bandgap was attributed in part, to the strain that accompanies this particular graphene growth. First measurements were in disordered forms of the material, a natural property of the growth mode. The last year has been devoted to “matching” SiC on the nanoscale to crate ordered form of the drained material. The matching makes use of a new tool at Rutgers employing a He ion microscope, an apparatus that produces a sub- nanometer He beam capable of machining the SiC substrata through atomic sputtering and material cutting.
